elements.title: Monthly Cost as Visual Anchor in Pricing Hierarchy
elements.problem: The guest's budget mental model is monthly, but the platform's pricing is per-night. Every time Shomit encounters a price, he must perform arithmetic to determine affordability. Visually, if the per-night rate is the largest, most prominent number on a listing card, the guest's eye lands on a number that does not answer their actual question ('Can I afford this per month?'). This visual mismatch between what the eye sees first and what the brain needs to evaluate creates a micro-friction at every listing touchpoint. Csikszentmihalyi's immediate-feedback principle requires that the answer to the guest's budget question be visually instantaneous — no computation, no scanning for secondary numbers.
elements.solution: Establish the monthly cost for the guest's selected schedule as the visually dominant number on every listing card and listing page. Use typographic scale, weight, and color to create an unambiguous hierarchy: the monthly figure is the largest, darkest, most prominent element in the pricing zone. The per-night rate is rendered smaller, lighter, and subordinate. A savings comparison line ('vs. $2,500/mo full lease') uses a muted color to provide context without competing for attention. The monthly figure should update in real time when the guest adjusts their schedule, with a brief transition animation (fade or count-up) that provides the 'immediate feedback' Csikszentmihalyi identifies as essential for engagement.

evidence.quote: I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night... Probably below 2,500 a month is what I would usually spend.
evidence.insight: The guest's visual scanning frame for prices is monthly. The largest number their eye encounters must be the monthly figure, or they must divert attention to compute it — breaking the immediate-feedback loop.

evidence.quote: four nights will be get $66 per night And that is including all taxes fees.
evidence.insight: The agent provides only the per-night rate. The guest must compute $66 x 4 x ~4.3 = ~$1,135/month. If the visual hierarchy mirrors this agent behavior (per-night first), the platform inherits the same cognitive burden the phone call imposed.

evidence.quote: The reason it is possible to achieve such complete involvement in a flow experience is that goals are usually clear, and feedback immediate.
evidence.insight: Budget evaluation is a feedback loop: 'Does this fit my budget?' The answer must be visually immediate. A large, prominent monthly figure provides instant feedback; a per-night figure that requires arithmetic provides delayed feedback, which breaks engagement.

typography: Outfit 700 28px (--text-2xl, --font-weight-bold) for the monthly cost figure on listing cards
IBM Plex Mono 400 12px (--text-sm) for the savings comparison line to signal data precision
spacing: --spacing-xs (4px) between monthly figure and per-night detail
--spacing-sm (8px) between pricing block and savings comparison
new_tokens_needed: --transition-number: 300ms ease-out for animated price updates when schedule changes

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Monthly figure (#1a1a1a on #ffffff) achieves 16.1:1 — exceeds AAA. Per-night detail (#6b7280 on #ffffff) achieves approximately 4.6:1 — meets AA for normal text. Savings line (#9ca3af on #ffffff) achieves approximately 2.6:1 — fails AA, use proposed --text-light-gray (#8891A0) at 4.5:1 instead to meet AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The monthly cost figure is the FIRST number the eye encounters in any pricing zone. It achieves visual dominance through three simultaneous signals: largest font size (28px vs. 14px for per-night), heaviest weight (700 vs. 400), and darkest color (#1a1a1a vs. #6b7280). No other numeric element in the pricing zone should compete with this triple-signal dominance.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md's 'Relentless Personalization' principle: the monthly figure is computed for the guest's specific schedule, not a generic rate. Aligns with 'Confident, not flashy' by using typographic hierarchy rather than decorative elements to communicate the most important number. Uses IBM Plex Mono for the savings comparison to signal 'precision and reliability' per the typography philosophy.

elements.title: Progressive Process Tracker with Phase-Aware Density
elements.problem: The guest journey spans two to three weeks across multiple phases, but there is no persistent visual indicator of progress. Shomit describes the process as 'courtship' — an open-ended, uncertain pursuit. Without visual progress feedback, each time the guest returns to the platform, they must reconstruct their mental model of where they are and what comes next. Csikszentmihalyi identifies that even long-duration activities sustain engagement when incremental feedback is visible ('I like to see them grow day by day'). The platform currently provides no equivalent of 'watching plants grow' for the guest's multi-week housing search process.
elements.solution: Design a persistent, compact process tracker that appears on every authenticated page. The tracker uses a horizontal step indicator with 5 named phases (Browse, Express Interest, Match, Meet, Sign). The current phase is visually highlighted with the brand accent color and slightly elevated through a subtle shadow. Completed phases use a muted fill. Future phases are outlined only, with reduced opacity. The tracker is compact by default (showing only the current step name and a progress line) and expands on interaction to show all steps. Crucially, the visual density of the tracker adapts to the guest's phase: early phases show a lightweight, unobtrusive bar; later phases (negotiation, acceptance) show more detail as the guest's investment and need for feedback increase.
elements.solution_continued: Between milestones, the tracker's current-step indicator should include a brief status line in a secondary typeface ('Matching in progress — expected by Feb 28'). After any guest action, the tracker animates forward with a smooth transition using the spring easing, providing the symbolic 'I have succeeded in my goal' feedback Csikszentmihalyi describes.

evidence.quote: It's usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process and get Lisa [lease].
evidence.insight: A multi-week process without visual progress markers creates a sustained feedback vacuum. The tracker provides the incremental visibility that sustains engagement across sessions.

evidence.quote: So like courtship.
evidence.insight: Courtship implies uncertainty about mutual interest. The tracker visually demonstrates that the platform is actively working on the guest's behalf (matching, scheduling), countering the perception that the guest is alone in an uncertain pursuit.

evidence.quote: Certain activities require a very long time to accomplish, yet the components of goals and feedback are still extremely important to them... 'I find special satisfaction in caring for the plants: I like to see them grow day by day. It is very beautiful.'
evidence.insight: The tracker is the digital equivalent of watching plants grow. Each phase completion is a visible growth event that sustains the guest's sense of forward movement.

evidence.quote: What makes this information valuable is the symbolic message it contains: that I have succeeded in my goal. Such knowledge creates order in consciousness.
evidence.insight: The tracker's animations and state changes carry symbolic value: 'You are advancing.' This symbolic message creates order in the guest's consciousness during a multi-week process that might otherwise feel chaotic.

--spacing-sm (8px) between step indicator dots
--spacing-xs (4px) between step name and status detail

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Active step label (#1a1a1a on #ffffff) achieves 16.1:1 — exceeds AAA. Status text (#6b7280 on #ffffff) achieves approximately 4.6:1 — meets AA. Future step outlines (#e5e7eb on #ffffff) are decorative, not informational, so contrast exemption applies — but step names must meet AA regardless of visual state.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The tracker is PERSISTENT SECONDARY infrastructure: always present on authenticated pages but never competing with primary page content. It occupies a fixed position (top of content area, below navigation) and uses a subtle bottom border to separate it from page content. The current step name is the eye's entry point within the tracker. The progress line provides peripheral context without demanding focused attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md's 'Premium-accessible' principle: the tracker feels high-quality through smooth animations and precise typography but does not overwhelm with complexity. Aligns with 'Fast response, gentle settle' animation philosophy: step completions trigger an immediate color change (< 100ms) followed by a smooth fill animation (300-500ms using spring easing). Aligns with 'Relentless Personalization': the tracker shows the guest's specific status, not a generic process diagram.

elements.title: Co-Tenancy Visual Explanation Through Spatial Diagrams
elements.problem: The co-tenancy concept is the most novel element of Split Lease, yet it is currently explained only through words — on a phone call ('ghost roommates') and, presumably, in text on the platform. Shomit's triple hedge ('I guess that's fine... I guess that's fine') reveals that verbal explanation alone does not resolve spatial uncertainty. When a guest hears 'two people share the same space at different times,' they need to SEE the arrangement to understand it. Text-based explanations of spatial relationships force the guest to construct a mental image, which is effortful, error-prone, and produces unresolved anxiety. A visual diagram that shows the time-split arrangement communicates the concept faster and more completely than any paragraph.
elements.solution: At every phase where co-tenancy is relevant, provide a visual spatial diagram rather than (or in addition to) text explanation. The diagram uses a simple two-color timeline: the guest's days are shown in the brand accent color, the co-tenant's days in a neutral gray, with clear separation between the two. The diagram is compact (fits in a single line), uses the same day-badge visual language already established in the style guide, and requires zero reading to understand. At discovery: the diagram appears alongside a single explanatory sentence. At listing evaluation: the diagram is integrated into the listing's schedule section, showing which days are the guest's and which are not. At negotiation: the diagram accompanies the co-tenant profile preview. At move-in: the diagram appears in arrival materials as a visual reminder of the schedule arrangement.

evidence.quote: Where does that other person go? ... I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.
evidence.insight: The guest's first co-tenancy question is spatial ('Where does that other person go?'). A spatial question demands a spatial answer — a visual diagram, not a verbal explanation. The triple hedge signals that the verbal answer did not fully resolve the spatial uncertainty.

evidence.quote: the two people who acting sort of like ghost roommates... the same space is used by different people in different types.
evidence.insight: The 'ghost roommates' metaphor is evocative but visually ambiguous. Does the guest picture overlapping presence? Alternating use? A diagram eliminates ambiguity by showing the exact temporal split.

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
evidence.insight: Guests evaluating a co-tenancy arrangement they have never experienced are in an analogous 'blind' state — they cannot see the reality. Visual diagrams compensate by providing spatial feedback that words cannot deliver.

elements.title: Comparison Grid with Aligned Data Points
elements.problem: Shomit refuses to act on any single listing until he has surveyed the full landscape ('No, I want to see what the other options are'). This means the search phase must support rapid visual comparison across multiple listings. If listing cards present information in inconsistent positions, with varying layouts, or with different levels of detail, the guest's eye must re-orient for each card — destroying the scanning speed that comparison requires. Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance applies: comparing listings from memory (open one, remember details, go back, open another) exceeds working memory capacity. Side-by-side visual comparison with aligned data points brings the challenge within the guest's capacity.
elements.solution: Design listing cards in search results as a strictly standardized grid where the same four data points appear in the exact same position on every card: (1) monthly cost (top-left, largest element), (2) neighborhood name (below price), (3) available night badges (compact row of day badges), (4) property photo thumbnail (right side or top). Every card in the grid uses identical dimensions, identical typography positions, and identical spacing. The data points are vertically aligned across cards in a grid layout so the guest can scan a column of prices, a column of neighborhoods, or a column of schedule badges without eye movement between columns. Filter controls are persistently visible above the grid and each filter change triggers an immediate results update with a subtle fade transition.

evidence.quote: No, I want to see what the other options are.
evidence.insight: The guest's primary search need is breadth, not depth. The visual design must support rapid scanning across many cards rather than deep engagement with one. Standardized card layout enables this scanning behavior.

evidence.quote: you can play with that on the website and it will give you all options dynamically. So you can see that.
evidence.insight: The agent promises dynamic, interactive search. Visually, this means filter changes must produce immediate visual feedback: results re-render with a brief transition, and the updated monthly costs are instantly visible in their standardized positions.

evidence.quote: Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.
evidence.insight: Comparing listings from memory is in the anxiety zone — too much cognitive load. A visual comparison grid with aligned data points brings the comparison challenge into the flow zone by eliminating the need for memorization.

evidence.quote: the experience usually occurs when we confront tasks we have a chance of completing... the task undertaken has clear goals and provides immediate feedback.
evidence.insight: A listing comparison feels completable when the guest can see all relevant data at once. Each filter adjustment provides immediate feedback (results change). This completability and feedback loop is essential for maintaining engagement during the search phase.

Each card is identical in structure, differing only in content — this restraint creates a sense of order and professionalism. Aligns with 'Premium-accessible' by making comparison effortless through design rather than requiring the guest to develop comparison skills. elements.title: Low-Commitment Action Button Visual Weight
elements.problem: Shomit refuses to 'bid' three times despite understanding it is non-binding. The visual weight of the action button contributes to this resistance: if the primary call-to-action on a listing page uses the full visual weight of a primary button (solid fill, bold color, strong shadow), it communicates 'this is a significant commitment step' even when the text says otherwise. The visual language of the button must match the actual commitment level of the action. Csikszentmihalyi's paradox of control reveals the mechanism: the guest will only act when they feel the action is an exercise of control, not a surrender of it. A visually heavy 'Place Bid' button frames the action as consequential; a visually light 'Save This Property' button frames it as organizational.
elements.solution: Design the expression-of-interest action (formerly 'bid') with deliberately reduced visual weight. Use a secondary button style: outlined border in the accent color rather than solid fill, normal font weight rather than bold, and no shadow. The button text should be 'Save this property' or 'Express interest' — language that matches the non-binding nature of the action. On hover, the button fills with a light tint of the accent color (accent-light) rather than transitioning to a full solid button, maintaining the sense of lightness. After the action is taken, the button transforms into a confirmation state ('Saved') with a subtle checkmark icon and accent-light background, providing the immediate feedback Csikszentmihalyi requires without suggesting the action was heavyweight.

evidence.quote: I'll still hold off. See the other ones.
evidence.insight: After three explanations that bids are non-binding, the guest still holds off. The resistance is not informational (he understands non-binding) but emotional — the action feels too heavy. The button's visual weight must be reduced to match the actual commitment level.

evidence.quote: a bead is not Samsung, which obligates you to lease it. It's your expression of interest for certain properties.
evidence.insight: The agent reframes the bid as an 'expression of interest.' The visual design of the button must complete this reframing: an outlined, lightweight button visually communicates 'expression of interest' better than a solid, heavyweight button.

evidence.quote: what people enjoy is not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations. It is not possible to experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines.
evidence.insight: The guest's protective routine is 'I'll hold off.' To coax them out of this routine, the action must feel safe enough to attempt. A visually lightweight button reduces the perceived risk, making it easier for the guest to exercise control by acting.

--accent-purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)) with ~0.08 opacity for hover background tint

If the button is more prominent than the price, it reverses this natural sequence and triggers premature action pressure.

elements.title: Verification Pathway Visual Prominence on Listings
elements.problem: Shomit asks 'is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?' — revealing he does not know whether physical or virtual verification exists. If the listing page buries verification options (tour, video walkthrough, lived-in photos) below the fold or behind interaction gates, the guest who needs sensory confirmation before committing will never discover these options exist. Csikszentmihalyi's feedback principle for the 'blind women' study is directly applicable: guests evaluating a space they have never seen need richer-than-usual visual feedback to compensate for the absence of direct sensory experience. The visual design must surface verification prominently, not as an afterthought.
elements.solution: Create a visually distinct 'Verify This Space' section on every listing page, positioned after the photo gallery and pricing but before the action button. The section uses a warm surface background (surface-warm or bg-off-white) to visually differentiate it from surrounding content, with a clear heading and two pathways: 'Schedule a Visit' (if available) and 'Take Virtual Tour' (always available). Each pathway is represented as a card-like element with an icon, label, and brief description. The section should use a subtle left border accent in the brand color to draw the eye without overwhelming. If the listing includes lived-in-condition photos (not just staged ones), these should be called out with a small badge: 'Actual condition' in mono font to signal trustworthiness.

evidence.quote: is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?
evidence.insight: The phrasing 'Is that allowed?' reveals the guest perceives verification as uncertain or restricted. The visual design must surface it proactively and prominently to counter this perception.

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing.
evidence.insight: Guests evaluating a listing remotely are 'blind' to the physical reality. They need compensatory visual feedback — tours, videos, actual-condition photos — and this feedback must be visually prominent, not hidden.

evidence.quote: the clearly structured demands of the activity impose order, and exclude the interference of disorder in consciousness.
evidence.insight: A clearly structured verification section imposes order on the guest's evaluation process: they know exactly where to find sensory confirmation, reducing the 'disorder in consciousness' that uncertainty about the space creates.

elements.title: Single-Concept Phase Introductions with Visual Breathing Room
elements.problem: During the initial call, the agent introduces six or more novel concepts in rapid succession: co-tenancy, schedule splitting, dynamic pricing, bidding, matching, Zoom meetings, lease timeline. Shomit's partial acceptance ('this is good, right? Except for like one or two things') followed by repeated deferral shows that information overload at any single touchpoint produces anxiety-zone behavior. Visually, if a page introduces multiple novel concepts simultaneously — through dense text blocks, multiple callout boxes, or a process diagram showing all steps at once — the guest's eye has no clear entry point and no rest between concepts. Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance requires that each new concept be introduced in isolation, with visual breathing room that allows the guest to absorb one idea before encountering the next.
elements.solution: At each phase transition, the platform should present a single-concept introduction: one heading, one short paragraph (maximum 2-3 lines), and one supporting visual element (diagram, icon, or example). This introduction occupies a generous vertical space with ample whitespace above and below, creating a visual 'clearing' that separates it from surrounding interface elements. The heading uses the serif font (Instrument Serif) for warmth and personality, the body uses the sans font (Outfit) for clarity, and any data element uses the mono font (IBM Plex Mono) for precision. The concept introduction should never share vertical space with navigation, filters, or action prompts — it stands alone as a moment of orientation before the guest proceeds.

evidence.quote: I guess like a few, this is good, right? Except for like one or two things.
evidence.insight: The guest signals partial absorption: the core value proposition landed, but unresolved items remain. Visual design should honor this partial-absorption pattern by presenting one concept fully before introducing the next, with breathing room between them.

evidence.quote: let me just a quick explain you how's this work... the two people who acting sort of like ghost roommates... the same space is used by different people... the cost for you is significantly less.
evidence.insight: The agent stacks co-tenancy, schedule splitting, and cost savings into one block. Visually, if a page mirrors this pattern (dense information block), the guest faces the same cognitive overload the phone call produced.

evidence.quote: Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.
evidence.insight: Six concepts at once is the anxiety zone. One concept with breathing room is the flow zone. The visual design must calibrate information density to one concept per visual 'clearing.'

evidence.quote: Any activity contains a bundle of opportunities for action, or 'challenges,' that require appropriate skills to realize. For those who don't have the right skills, the activity is not challenging; it is simply meaningless.
evidence.insight: Concepts introduced before the guest has context are meaningless, not challenging. Visually, future-phase information should be invisible, not dimmed or collapsed — truly absent from the page.

elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md's 'Confident, not flashy' principle: the introduction communicates through clarity and whitespace rather than decorative elements or visual density. The use of Instrument Serif for the heading follows the typography philosophy of 'serif for personality (headlines, brand)' — creating a warm, approachable entry point. Aligns with 'Premium-accessible': generous whitespace and a relaxed line height create a reading experience that feels high-quality and unhurried. Aligns with animation philosophy: the concept introduction appears with a single subtle fade-in (transition-slow, 0.3s) — 'one signature animation per component.'
